title: How long do I need to live in a house before I can claim a homestead exemption on it for chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: I have a trailer I'm currently living in, but I have a house in my name that my child is living in but can no longer afford. I'd like to keep the equity in that house. I'm thinking of moving into the house so I can claim homestead exemption. But can this be a problem? If I decide to just start living there from now on, is that ok?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy exemptions,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Claiming a homestead is an issue involving your intention. I have had client's throw a sleeping bag on the couch of an empty home and as long as they intend to stay (as long as needed to obtain the homestead), they could claim the homestead the following morning. In terms of running for public office in Nevada, the Nevada Supreme Court has held that your home is where your cat sleeps. Hope this perspective helps!
You need to live in the home to claim the exemption. I do not see any issue as this is your home and you can move into it.

Each state has its own homestead rules. For example in Washington, you are presumed to have a homestead where you live. But you can file a Declaration of HOmestead on other property even if you are not living on it if you fulfill the terms of the law which is usually to in fact intend to live on it. Thus, speak to an experienced Bankruptcy Attorney in CA on both situations or more onto the property before filing. But bankruptcy also involves other issues.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

As you know, you have to really and actually live in the property you're claiming as a homestead. Since the property is already vested in your name, you should be able to simply move back in BEFORE you file BK. If anyone (creditor, for example), knows your address is different, you may have a problem, but if you really move in, transfer the utilities back into your name, you should be OK. Be sure to check with a local BK lawyer in your area, but i think the rules are the same. Good luck to you.
